problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place unit fraction on pre-partitioned 0-1 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with tick marks pre-placed at all fraction positions for the given denominator. Only 0 and 1 are labeled.
prompt_examples: Place one-third on the number line.
Click where one-fourth goes.
Where is 1/3? Select the correct tick mark.
action_description: Student clicks on the tick mark that represents the target unit fraction or labels the correct tick mark.
correct_end_state: The correct tick mark is in clicked or selected state
success_dialogue: That's right, one-third. One interval from zero.
Yes, that's one-fourth.
Correct, that's where one-fifth goes.

problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place unit fraction with scaffolded visual hints
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with tick marks pre-placed at all fraction positions for the given denominator. Only 0 and 1 are labeled.
prompt_examples: Click where one-half goes. One interval from zero.
Select 1/4 on the number line. One interval from zero.
Place one-fourth. One interval from zero.
action_description: Student clicks on the first tick mark after zero
correct_end_state: Point appears at clicked position; label appears
success_dialogue: You found it! One space from zero.
That's right, one-half is one interval from zero.
Good. One-third is one space from zero.

problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place non-unit fraction on pre-partitioned 0-1 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with tick marks pre-placed at all fraction positions for the given denominator. Only 0 and 1 are labeled.
prompt_examples: Place three-fourths on the number line.
Click where two-thirds goes.
Where is 3/8? Select the correct tick mark.
action_description: Student clicks on the tick mark representing the target non-unit fraction by counting numerator intervals from zero
correct_end_state: Point appears at the clicked tick mark; fraction label appears
success_dialogue: That's three-fourths, three intervals from zero.
Right, that's 2/3.
Correct, 3/5 is the third fifth from zero.

problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place non-unit fraction with scaffolded hints
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with tick marks pre-placed at all fraction positions for the given denominator. Only 0 and 1 are labeled.
prompt_examples: Place three-fourths, three intervals from zero.
Select 2/3 on the number line. That's two spaces.
Click where 3/4 goes. Count the intervals: 1/4, 2/4, 3/4.
action_description: Student clicks on tick mark after counting highlighted intervals
correct_end_state: Point appears at clicked position; label appears
success_dialogue: That's three-fourths, three intervals from zero.
Right, that's 2/3.
Correct, 3/5 is the third fifth from zero.

problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place fraction beyond 1 on extended 0-2 number line
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 2 with tick marks pre-placed at all fourths positions (0, 1/4, 2/4, 3/4, 1, 5/4, 6/4, 7/4, 2). Labels at 0, 1, and 2.
prompt_examples: Place five-fourths on the number line.
Locate 5/4 on the number line.
Click where seven-fourths goes.
action_description: Student clicks on the tick mark beyond 1 that represents the target fraction
correct_end_state: Point appears at the clicked tick mark; fraction label appears
success_dialogue: Yes, that's five-fourths, one interval past 1.
Good. That's 6/4, two fourths past 1.
Right, seven-fourths is seven intervals from 0.

problem_type: Student clicks tick mark to place fraction beyond 1 with scaffolded SUPPORT
prompt_examples: Find five-fourths, count five intervals from zero.
5/4 is one more than 4/4. Click where it goes.
Place five-fourths. Count five spaces from zero.
action_description: Student clicks tick mark one space after the 1 position
correct_end_state: Point appears at 5/4 position; label appears
success_dialogue: Good, you correctly selected five-fourths!
Correct, that's 3/2. Halfway between 1 and 2.
Nice, you placed four-thirds on the number line.

problem_type: Student counts intervals on number line to identify the denominator (MCQ)
workspace_description: Horizontal number line from 0 to 1 with tick marks pre-placed. MCQ options appear below with adjacent numbers (e.g., 3, 4, 5).
prompt_examples: What would be the denominator of a fraction on this number line?
Count the intervals between 0 and 1. How many are there?
Look at this number line. How many spaces from 0 to 1?
action_description: Student selects the number that represents the count of intervals from the options
correct_end_state: Selected answer highlighted as correct; intervals may flash to confirm
success_dialogue: Yes, four spaces means fourths.
Right, you counted three intervals.
Correct. Six equal intervals show sixths.

problem_type: Student identifies the fraction represented by a point already placed on 0-1 number line (MCQ)
workspace_description: Number line 0-1 with a point already placed at a fraction position. MCQ options show possible fractions.
prompt_examples: What fraction does this point show?
Look at where the point is. What fraction is that?
Name the fraction at this position.
action_description: Student selects the matching fraction from the options or drags the correct fraction to the point
correct_end_state: Selected answer highlighted; fraction label appears at point
success_dialogue: Yes, that's two-thirds. Two spaces from zero.
That's right, 3/4 is three fourths from zero.
Right, you correctly selected one-fifth.

problem_type: Student identifies the fraction represented by a point placed beyond 1 (MCQ)
workspace_description: Number line 0-2 with a point placed beyond 1. MCQ options show beyond-1 fractions.
prompt_examples: What fraction does this point show?
Look at where the point is. What fraction is that?
Name the fraction at this position.
action_description: Student selects the matching fraction from the options or drags the correct fraction to the point
correct_end_state: Selected answer highlighted; fraction label appears at point
success_dialogue: Yes, that's two-thirds. Two spaces from zero.
That's right, 3/4 is three fourths from zero.
Right, you correctly selected one-fifth.

problem_type: Student selects which number line shows a specific fraction type (comparison)
workspace_description: Three horizontal number lines (0-1) shown vertically stacked, each with different interval counts. Student selects the one matching the target.
prompt_examples: Which number line shows fourths?
Find the line divided into thirds.
One of these shows fifths. Which one?
action_description: Student selects the the line with a target count
success_dialogue: That one—four equal spaces for fourths.
Right. Three equal intervals means thirds.
Correct! You found the line with fifths.

problem_type: Student compares 2-3 points on different number lines to identify which is larger.
workspace_description: 2-3 number lines (labelled at 0 and 1) partitioned into same number of intervals with one unlabelled point placed on each line at different fraction positions for comparison and the options reflect the fractions on each of the labelled points
prompt_examples: Which point shows the larger fraction?
Look at the two points. Which is farther from 0?
Which fraction is greater distance from 0?
action_description: Student selects the number line with a point at the larger fraction.
success_dialogue: Yes three-fourths, further from zero means more.
Right. More spaces from zero show larger fraction.
Correct, four-fifths is greater. You can see it's further from 0.

problem_type: Student identifies fraction in context describing something beyond 1 (application)
prompt_examples: Sam walked 5 spaces on a fourths number line starting at 0. What fraction did Sam reach?
A frog jumped 6 equal fourths from 0. Where did it land?
The marker shows 7 intervals from zero on a fourths line. What fraction is that?
action_description: Student places a point at the appropriate fraction tick on the number line.
success_dialogue: Five spaces from zero—five-fourths.
Right! Six intervals means 6/4.
Seven-fourths. Past one whole.

problem_type: Student identifies equal vs unequal intervals (identify)
workspace_description: Three horizontal number lines (0-1) vertically stacked, one of the number lines shows correct number of equal intervals, one shows incorrect number of equal intervals and one shows correct number of unequal intervals.
prompt_examples: Select the number line that shows fourths.
One of the lines is partitioned into thirds. Select this line.
action_description: Student identifies the line with correct number of equal intervals and selects it.
success_dialogue: Yes, this line has four equal intervals.
Right! Three equal intervals for thirds.
